response_parsed.title: Deep Dive: Random Standard Library Module in Python 3.12+
response_parsed.summary: This explainer delves into the new features and enhancements of the Random module in Python 3.12+, providing a comprehensive guide to its use.
key_points: Improved performance and efficiency due to optimizations.
New functions for generating distributions such as exponential, Pareto, and Rayleigh.
Support for generating correlated random variables with the help of Cholesky decomposition.
Enhanced seeding options including a new function to set seeds across multiple processes.

code_examples.code:
import random

# Generate an exponential distribution
exp_val = random.expovariate(1.5)
print(exp_val)

import numpy as np

# Generate correlated normal distributions using Cholesky decomposition
A = np.array([[1, 0.5], [0.5, 1]])
cov_mat = np.linalg.cholesky(A)
mean = np.zeros((2, 1))
corr_val = random.multivariate_normal(mean, cov_mat)

version_notes: Python 3.12.0 and above are required to access these new features.
For earlier versions, consider using the numpy library's random functions as a workaround.
caveats: The Cholesky decomposition method may not always provide accurate results when the input matrix is not positive definite.
Using multiple seeding options can make your code less reproducible, so choose wisely and document your decisions.
